awd_titl_txt: RII Track-2 FEC: Collaborative Research: Harnessing Big Data to Improve Understanding and Predictions of Geomagnetically Induced Currents
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently, the Office of Science and Technology for the President recommended that we take steps to prepare our nation's infrastructure to withstand the hazardous space weather impacts. Geomagnetically induced currents (GICs), caused by the geomagnetic disturbance during space weather events, can produce power outages, train system failures, and pipeline corrosion. Although the risk of GICs are widely acknowledged in the industry and space science community, the occurrence patterns and the space/ground conditions responsible for GICs are poorly understood mainly because power companies are hesitant to provide their GIC data due to a possible legal dispute over the power outages and any other technical problems. The project will take advantage of the wealth of expertise in space physics and data science within the University of Alaska Fairbanks and the University of New Hampshire to understand and predict the GICs. This project specifically focuses on the geomagnetic disturbance, the trigger of GICs, and the possible sources of such disturbance in our geospace environments. We will apply the state-of-the-art machine learning techniques to over two decades of space/ground-based observations and develop two prediction models for the geomagnetic disturbance and the GIC-risk, both of which will be provided to NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center at the end of project. Additionally, we will improve our GIC predictions in Alaska and New Hampshire, the two high GIC-risk states, via the Space Weather Underground (SWUG) program. Under this program, high-school and undergraduate students will build and deploy magnetometers, measure geomagnetic disturbances, and analyze the data. By varying the spatial distance between the magnetometers, we can investigate the optimal number and distribution of ground magnetometers for accurate GIC modeling and prediction. The project team includes early-career and under-represented scientists and will provide research projects and relevant course content to high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students, including those at a minority serving institution and regional colleges.

Recently, the Office of Science and Technology for the President recommended that we take steps to prepare our nation's infrastructure to withstand the hazardous space weather impacts. Geomagnetically induced currents (GICs), caused by the geomagnetic disturbance during space weather events, can produce power outages, train system failures, and pipeline corrosion. Although the risk of GICs are widely acknowledged in the industry and space science community, the occurrence patterns and the space/ground conditions responsible for GICs are poorly understood mainly because power companies are hesitant to provide their GIC data due to a possible legal dispute over the power outages and any other technical problems. The project will take advantage of the wealth of expertise in space physics within the Geophysical Institute at the U. of Alaska (UAF) and the Space Science Center at the U. of New Hampshire (UNH) combined with data science expertise at both universities to understand and predict the GICs. This project specifically focuses on the geomagnetic disturbance, the trigger of GICs, and the possible sources of such disturbance in solar wind, magnetosphere, and ionosphere. We will apply the state-of-the-art machine learning techniques to over two decades of space/ground-based observations and develop two prediction models for the geomagnetic disturbance and the GIC-risk, both of which will be provided to NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center at the end of project. Additionally, the UNH Space Weather Underground (SWUG) program will be expanded within New Hampshire and to UAF. Under this program, high-school and undergraduate students will build and deploy magnetometers and analyze the data. By varying the spatial distance between the magnetometers, we can investigate the optimal number and distribution of ground magnetometers for accurate GIC modeling and prediction. Additionally, the SWUG dataset will improve the GIC predictions in AK and NH. Alaska is in a region of high latitude with increased GIC risk. New Hampshire is at lower latitudes, but includes coastal areas as well as bedrock with high resistivity, which forces the currents to flow through structures such as power transmission lines. Thus, these two states provide ideal conditions for collaboration and comparison of results and would benefit from improved predictive capabilities for GICs. The proposed project would open new funding opportunities for project participants within NSF and elsewhere by supporting new interdisciplinary and inter-jurisdictional collaborations and building capacity for future big data science in space weather research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

MAGICIAN Project Outcomes

The sun constantly sends out a stream of charged particles called the solar wind. When this solar wind is configured in certain ways it will energize particles in Earth’s magnetosphere (the region in space where Earth’s magnetic field dominates) producing several phenomena that impact Earth’s upper atmosphere and human infrastructure – including satellites, power grids and radio transmission. Together these phenomena have been given the name Space Weather, and are a national concern given our increased reliance on electrical and data infrastructure.  For example, during a 1989 solar storm, the currents in our upper atmosphere associated with strong northern lights (aurora) events caused damage to power transformers, which then caused a cascade of failures that resulted in a multi-hour power outage in Quebec. This damage was caused by electrical currents induced in the ground and the power lines, technically called geomagnetically induced currents, or GICs, due to rapid and large changes in the local magnetic field, caused by the auroral currents.  At that time there was little information that could be used to predict that storm or the events. Now we have satellites that can track and measure the solar storm strength and timing, and have an array of ground-based sensors that can measure the impacts of those storms.

Two groups, one from the University of Alaska Fairbanks, and the other from the University of New Hampshire, collaborated to examine ways to predict the impacts of solar storms on modern infrastructure, especially the effects of GICs. Specifically, we wanted to use machine learning (ML) techniques to make this possible. Machine learning uses algorithms that match patterns in a variety of data sets, and then applies those matching patterns to incoming data sets to make predictions on how a system might respond given those data.

There are many types and flavors of ML algorithms. Our teams tested the ability of several of these algorithms to predict when and where large GICs might occur by examining the solar wind data collected by two satellites – ACE and DISCOVR. These satellites are outside of the Earth’s magnetosphere and collect a running record of the information on several parameters of the solar wind. The location of these satellites is about 60 to 90 minutes ahead of where that solar wind will impact Earth’s magnetosphere. A key result of this project shows that several ML algorithms examining solar wind parameters do a very good job of predicting the timing and location of large changes in ground magnetic field, but tend to underestimate the magnitude of those changes. This is because the prediction capability requires the examination of a large training dataset, but there are a lot more quiet time data than the more extreme events that are most critical to predict, so the training for large events is not as extensive. This will be improved by data collected in this current, more active, solar cycle, where there have already been two large magnetic storms.

Another key result is that there are some significant asymmetries in the timing and magnitude of rapid magnetic fluctuations between the northern and southern hemisphere. As this is a statistical study it is not clear what the physical source of the asymmetry is, ground conductivity or something inherent in the magnetosphere. But this study has documented the effect so that future modelers and data analysts can use this to understand the mechanism.

Finally, the two groups used ML techniques for images to categorize aurora images using unsupervised learning  and analyzing them with respect to ground magnetic field variations showed that discrete aurora labels are associated with stronger changes in magnetic variations in the pre-midnight sector, while diffuse aurora labels are associated with stronger magnetic variations in the post-midnight sector. There is also a relationship between different types of aurora forms and rapid magnetic variations. This enables another method for predicting effects of auroral storms on GIC production even in the absence of magnetic field measurements.

This is just a small sample of all the intense and detailed work conducted on this project by a diverse and dedicated team. Cross-institutional mentoring actively occurred through monthly meetings, informal meetings, and frequent email conversations.
Over the course of the collaboration, four postdoctoral associates, eight graduate students, and at least six undergraduate students participated in MAGICIAN related projects. The Space Weather Underground (SWUG) project started in New Hampshire, where high school students build and use data from magnetometers, was expanded across New England, to Alaska, and to other regions in the US. The UNH SWUG team has deployed six units and the Alaska SWUG team has deployed eleven. During the five-year SWUG program UAF ran four week-long training classes for Alaskan teachers in which 28 teachers completed the training.
